items.title: :has has broad browser backing
items.content:
ğŸ„Â This is the final issue of Frontend Focus in 2023, and there's plenty to check out before we sign off! Thank you so much for reading along with us this year â€”Â as ever, we hope the newsletter continues to provide you value and shines a light on helpful resources. We'll be back on January 3rd with a look back over the biggest stories and tools shared throughout 2023. Catch youÂ then!
__
Your editor, Chris Brandrick

ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹623 â€” December 20, 2023 | Read on the web

Getting Started with Web Performance â€” A solid look at how to up your web performance game, with strategies, tools and tips to help you make notable improvements. Lots of additional resources shared here too to help you push thingsÂ further. Maybe a nice end of year project, making things speedier as we head into the new year?

Alistair Shepherd

Firefox 121 Released: New Features, Updates & Fixes â€” A big release of Firefox just before the holidays (it shipped yesterday), featuring support for the :has() selector, <iframe> lazy loading, updated text-wrap property support, and more. Full developer-focused notesÂ here.

Mozilla

â­ï¸ RELATED: Following the release of Firefox 121, :has() is now supported across all major browsers. Wes Bos runs through the possibilities itÂ unlocks.

Session Replay Basics - Debug Web App IssuesÂ Faster â€” Tired of â€œworks fine on my machineâ€ and spending time chasing elusive issues (like Hydration errors)? Join us on Jan 11th to learn how Session Replay can help confirm and resolve even the most difficult-to-repro issues in JavaScriptÂ applications.

Sentry sponsor

Baseline in 2023 â€” Baseline is now added to the invaluable Can I Use. Rachel explains how the new integration works here, and highlights what features became part of the Baseline inÂ 2023.

Rachel Andrew

Figma and Adobe Abandon Proposed Merger â€” 15 months after announcing the deal, the companies no longer see a path toward regulatoryÂ approval. Figma will get a meaty billion dollar check from Adobe.

Dylan Field (Figma)

âš¡ï¸ Quick Links

  • ğŸ‰ Centering content in CSS is going to get easier, for real.

  • ğŸ—“ï¸ A look over the new additions to Chrome and the web platform at large over the last month (including the aforementioned :has(), and changes to CSS Nesting parsing).

  • ğŸ¦Š Jecelyn Yeen explains how Puppeteer now talks to Firefox, building upon previous experimental support.

  • ğŸ›¡ï¸ There's a new 'Micro' set of 16x16 pixel icons in Heroicons v2.1 (an SVG icon set from the Tailwind CSSÂ folks).

  • ğŸ‘ Chrome now defaults to desktop mode on high-end Android tablets.

  • ğŸ“˜ Here's a free browser-based ebook from Alex Baranov on good typography practices for user interfaces.

  • â„ï¸ If you want to add snow to your site for a festive feeling, Zach has you covered with this web component.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

CSS animation-composition â€” How to use the CSS animation-composition property for advanced control over how values are applied during keyframeÂ animations.

Tyler Gaw

ğŸ¤¨ Bramus Van Damme follows up to the above, explaining the quirks of using animation-composition: accumulate on a scale transform.

CSS Scroll Snapping Aligned with Global Page Layout: A Full-Width Slider Case Study â€” Have you run into a situation where you need the padding of one element to align with the padding of another element? This article demonstrates the issue with a full-width slider component that breaks out of the main page container, sharing a couple of techniques to keep it visually aligned with other elements on theÂ page.

Brecht De Ruyte

Kickstart Your 2024 Developer Career with Scrimba â€” Scrimbaâ€™s online bootcamp can turn you into a hireable Frontend Dev in 3-6 months. Frontend Focus readers get 25% off! Offer ends DecÂ 31.

Scrimba sponsor

The Shrinkwrap Problem: Possible Future Solutions â€” How anchor positioning can help tackle a CSS problem: shrinking containers to fit content when it automaticallyÂ wraps.

Roman Komarov

Using Date-Based CSS to Make Old Web Pages Look Old â€” Explores a way to access the published date metadata of a page in order to change the CSS based on itsÂ age.

Terence Eden

Three Modern CSS Properties Your Site Must Have â€” A look at three â€œlesser-known CSS secretsâ€ that can go some way to help fix some UI problems on yourÂ website.

Mojtaba Seyedi

â–¶Â Â Igalia Chats: 2023 Year in Review â€” Brian Kardell and Eric Meyer chat with Chrome DevRel Bramus Van Damme, reviewing the year of change in the Web Platform in an hour longÂ discussion.

Igalia podcast

Locking Scroll with :has() â€” A neat, handy little trick that uses :has() to prevent accidental page scrolling when modals areÂ open.

Robb Owen

Ten Optimization Tips for an Initial Web Perf Audit
Alistair Shepherd

Fallbacks for HTTP 404 Images in HTML and JS
Salma Alam-Naylor

26 Web Dev Terms You May Not Have Heard Of
Jens Oliver Meiert

A Mental Model for Styling the Shadow DOM
Nathan Knowler

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Announcing SvelteKit 2 â€” SvelteKit (the official toolkit for building Svelte webapps) is now one year old, and despite its relative youth, the framework has been quickly embraced by the community. This release is a relatively incremental one, adding support for Vite 5, and laying the groundwork for SvelteÂ 5.

Svelte

Empowering a Creator Economy with â€˜Game-Changingâ€™ Analytics Dashboards â€” See how Patch helps Hubla deliver interactive, customer-facing analytics dashboards with zero infrastructureÂ setup.

Patch sponsor

pagefind-search Web Component â€” This implements PageFind search in an Eleventy app using Eleventy island support (via the is-landÂ component).

Zach Leatherman

Open Source Software: Open Source Alternatives to PopularÂ Projects â€” Currently includes 500+ projects that can be searched via keyword or via category filters (analytics, APIs, monitoring, terminal, authentication, etc).

john rush

NinjaBootstrap: A Collection of SCSS Utilities to Extend BootstrapÂ 5 â€” Includes utilities for spacing, positioning, sizing, borders, and color theming, allowing you to have a little more control over Bootstrapâ€™s defaultÂ classes.

Live Canvas

SVG.io: Generate Custom SVG Images from a Text Prompt â€” Simpler prompts will have better results and itâ€™s free to use with no limitations (for now!). The generated SVG is monochrome but could be customized in your SVG editor ofÂ choice. I had mixed success, but it's an interestingÂ idea.

Digital Pixel

Catch you in two weeks! â€” Chris ğŸ‘‹

Ipx.

items.title: 2023 was kind to CSS and the web platform
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹622 â€” December 13, 2023 | Read on the web

CSS Wrapped: 2023 â€” 2023 was truly a huge year for all things CSS. This detailed post from the Chrome teams brings together all of the headline features that landed in Chrome and across the web platform this year, including nesting, new color functions, the :has selector, linear-easing, and much much more. Thereâ€™s been so much added to our CSS tool belt this year, that this recap may prove handy in reminding us all what we can now actuallyÂ do.

Chrome for Developers

WebKit Features in Safari 17.2 â€” The WebKit team are closing out the year with a sizeable release of Safari, packing in 39 new features and over 150 various fixes. Notable additions include richer CSS nesting support, new math functions, support for preloading responsive images, new sizing units â€”Â including the likes of cap, ch, and ex. Lots to dig intoÂ here.

Jen Simmons and Marcos CÃ¡ceres (WebKit)

New TypeScript Courses: Take the Learning Path â€” Join Mike North (Tech Lead at Stripe) for this series of brand new TypeScript courses. You'll get hands-on practice covering both the fundamentals and advanced features like utility types and advanced generics. Learn best practices to configure and evolve your TSÂ codebase!

Frontend Masters sponsor

You Don't Need JavaScript for That â€” Killian notes that a core principle of web development is choosing the least powerful language suitable for a given purpose. In practice this means preferring HTML over CSS, and then CSS overÂ JS.

Killian Valkhof

HTML5 Boilerplate v9.0.0 Released â€” A bit of a blast from the past! This popular frontend template (with over 50k stars on GitHub) was last updated over three years ago, but is back with a flurry of sensible changes. GitHubÂ repo.

Rob Larsen

âš¡ï¸ Quick Links

  • ğŸ—³ï¸ It's the final week to take the State of JavaScript survey for 2023.

  • ğŸ—“ï¸ Tis the season for advent calendars full of themed web dev content, and Adrian Roselli has a round-up of all the ones worth keeping an eye on here.

  • ğŸ’¬ Eric Meyer reflects on three decades of writing HTML.

  • ğŸŸï¸ Beta invites for the Windows version of the Arc Browser are being sent out.

  • ğŸ¤ WordPress's Matt Mullenweg recently delivered his annual 'State of the Word' keynote, outlining where the popular CMS is, and where it's heading.

  • ğŸ”— Remy Sharp is working on unrot.link a service, which he explains here, promises to prevent and undo link rot on long lived web sites.

  • ğŸ“‘ Netlifyâ€™s State of Web Development Report for 2023 isÂ out.

  • ğŸ Need a last-minute gift? This typographic tear-off calendar isÂ lovely.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Preparing For Interaction To Next Paint, A New Web Core Vital â€” Starting in March, â€˜Interaction to Next Paintâ€™ will formally replace â€˜First Input Delayâ€™ as a Core Web Vital metric. Hereâ€™s how the two metrics differ, why we needed a new way to measure interaction responsiveness, and how you can start optimizing the performance of your site for a seamless transition to this newÂ metric.

Geoff Graham

An Interactive Guide to SVG Loading Spinners â€” Lots of good visuals and code examples here showing us, step-by-step, how to create neat looking SVG loading spinners (using attributes like stroke-dasharray and stroke-dashoffset).

SÃ©bastien NoÃ«l

[Live Tomorrow] Finding and Fixing JavaScript Code CausingÂ Slowdowns â€” Learn how to take action on Web Vitals, find code-level bottlenecks, and speed up load times for good. Join usÂ online.

Sentry sponsor

How to Use Responsive HTML Video (...and Audio) â€” The responsive video standard now works across all majorÂ browsers.

Scott Jehl

Lost in Translation: Tips for Multilingual Web Accessibility â€” Some practical tips for navigating the intersection between web accessibility andÂ internationalization/localization.

Ben Myers

How to Use Chrome's 'Accessibility Tree' â€” A look at what the accessibility tree is, how to access it, and how to use itsÂ information.

Whitney Lewis

How I Brought My LCP Down to Under 350 ms for Google-Referred Users â€” An exploration of the techniques used to optimize performance on a high-trafficÂ website.

PaweÅ‚ Pokrywka

Simplifying Web Performance with a Single UX Score
Sander van Surksum

A Coder Considers the Waning Days of the Craft
James Somers

Browsing the Eastern Side of the Personal Web
bikobatanari

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Epic Easing: An Interactive Tool to Generate Custom Easing Functions â€” A fun way to mess around with and learn easing functions, with lots of pre-built examples. The tool also lets you export as CSS, SCSS, Swift, and evenÂ Objective-C.

Meritt Thomas

AutoAnimate: Add Motion to Your Apps with a Single Line of Code â€” You can view some nice examples on the page and this can be used with React, Vue, Svelte, or just plainÂ JavaScript.

FormKit

Build with the Power of Code â€” Without Writing Any â€” Take control of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript in a visual canvas. Webflow generates clean code, ready toÂ publish.

Webflow sponsor

Clamp Calculator: Generate Custom CSS for Fluid Typography Using clamp() â€” A helper for fluid type in responsive designs that allows you to generate any number of custom properties using CSSâ€™s clamp() function, representing fluid type tokens you can drop into aÂ project.

James Gilyead and Trys Mudford

UserStock: Free Photos of People's Faces to Use as Avatars in Mockups and Prototypes â€” Includes drop-downs to filter using one of five different age groups and/or image style, but most importantly: these are not AI-generatedÂ images.

UserStock

SVGO 3.1: A Node.js-Powered SVG Optimizer â€” If youâ€™ve worked with SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics) at all, youâ€™ve probably seen they can be filled with all sorts of junk code.. SVGO to theÂ rescue.

Kir Belevich

Color Lisa: A Curated List of Color Palettes Based onÂ Masterpieces â€” A unique way to get some color inspiration from those who've used color best. Scroll alphabetically through artist names and view a hex-based color palette for that artistâ€™s most famous piece ofÂ work.

RYAN MCGUIRE

Keep React: A Library of 40+ Components Built with React and Tailwind â€” View all the components in the docs here, where youâ€™ll find lots of interactiveÂ demos.

StaticMania

Better Commits: A CLI for Creating Better Commits Following the Conventional Commit Guidelines
Erik Verduin

CodeSnaps: A Component Library Built with Tailwind and Next.js
Kaumon A

Ipx.

items.title: Should web perf tools report carbon emissions?
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹621 â€” December 6, 2023 | Read on the web

Taking Care Beyond Code: 7 Best Design Practices for Frontend Developers â€” When a frontend engineer fails to think about the importance of design, the user experience can suffer. This post highlights the importance of a holistic approach, offering pointers and best practices to ultimately result in less bugs and overallÂ delays.

Nina Torgunakova

ğŸš€ Â Astro 4.0 Released â€” The new major release of the Astro content-site framework is just out, including a new dev toolbar, automatic i18n routing, new view transition APIs, and more. Thereâ€™s also, experimentally, incremental content caching. Upgrading is simple â€“ an npx @astrojs/upgrade away for most folks.

Astro

AI in Content Management Done Right â€” With AI assisting marketers, tech people can finally focus on their strengths - apply a code-first approach, avoid code debt, design high-quality structures for content, and be prepared for theÂ future.

Kontent.ai sponsor

An Informed Pre-Caching Strategy for Large Sites â€” Pre-caching, also called cache priming or cache warming, involves preemptively putting items into the cache before they are requested by a user. Ethan shares how this can be a great way to reduce expensive computations and strain on the origin server, but notes that once a site gets to a certain scale, it requires more thought than simply keeping everything in a warmedÂ cache.

Ethan Gardner

âš¡ï¸ Quick Links

  • ğŸ”Ÿ It's been a decade since Troy Hunt launched the invaluable 'Have I Been Pwned' service. ThankÂ you!

  • ğŸ“‰ Bruce Wray looks at the stats and asks: is Firefox 'on theÂ brink'?

  • ğŸ¤¦ The UK government is exploring AI face detection to age-gate adultÂ content.

  • âŒ¨ï¸ It's from 2020, but this Advent calendar of accessibility tips remainsÂ useful.

  • â˜€ï¸ Do you think you'd ever use an au CSS size unit? Yes, 1au would be about 93 million miles orÂ so...Â ğŸ˜

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Why Web Perf Tools Should Be Reporting Website CarbonÂ Emissions â€” A response to a DebugBear post explaining why the company opts not to report carbon emissions in their reports. Fershad gently suggests why they should, chiefly to allow developers the opportunity to contextualize the impact of theirÂ sites.

Fershad Irani

sizes="auto" Pretty Much Requires Width and HeightÂ Attributes â€” Eric notes that â€˜auto-sizesâ€™ for lazy-loaded images is a fantastic addition to the web platform, but they curiously do basically require a width and height attribute.

Eric Portis

The AI Engineer Path Just Launched ğŸš€ â€” Supercharge your web dev skills with this JS focused AI Engineer course. Frontend Focus Readers get 62% off AnnualÂ plans.

Scrimba sponsor

Does Interaction to Next Paint Actually Correlate to UserÂ Behavior? â€” Now that Interaction to Next Paint is poised to dethrone FID as the Core Web Vitals metric for responsiveness, itâ€™s time to scrutinize itsÂ effectiveness.

Cliff Crocker

Examples of Great URL Design â€” Some examples of good URLs and why following certain patterns might be helpful. â€œTheyâ€™re not just for typing into browserÂ bars.â€

Jim Nielsen

Measure LCP Sub-Parts to Improve Largest Contentful Paint
DebugBear

Creating a Marquee Effect with CSS Animations
Ben Nadel

How HTML Web Components are 'Having a Moment'
Scott Vandehey

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

ClassyFont: An Online Tool to Generate CSS for Your Fonts â€” Upload your web-friendly fonts and this tool will generate the necessary @font-face code. You can edit the URL paths, the font fallbacks, and the naming style (camel case, hyphen, underscore).

sakar hamasaid

Pravatar: Avatar Placeholder Photos Under a CC0 License â€” Provides an API so you can access a random image, specifying the size, or choose a specific image from all those available by image ID, all sourced from Pexels.

simular

A Non-Cloud Alternative to Google Forms That Has It All â€” Transform your form management. Build and edit dynamic JSON-based forms in a form builder fully integrated in yourÂ IT.

SurveyJS sponsor

Design2Code: Use AI to Convert Any Web Design Screenshot to Clean HTML/CSS Code â€” Claims to support sketches, wireframes, Figma, XD, etc. Requires an OpenAI API key and the demo video shows an HTML form being converted from an image to responsive HTML/CSS. YMMV for other types ofÂ layouts!

Mostafa Sadeghi

ğŸ”¥ Hot fonts

  • I've stumbled across a handful of nice, interesting new fonts lately, so I figured I'd share a few of them here with you:
  • First up is Geist, a new pair of clean, versatile fonts from Vercel. There's two typeface variants here, Geist Sans and Geist Mono.

The much-loved Inter font just hit version 4.0. This new release has several new OpenType features, redesigns to thousands of glyphs, six additional display designs, and more. You can download it here.

Berkeley Mono is a lovely (paid) monofaced typeface "by software engineers, for software engineers" that's described as a "love letter to the golden era of computing". There's lots of examples here of it in use. It comes with several sets, plenty of ligatures, and has wider international/language support.

Snoo! Reddit recently underwent a brand redesign, and as part of that theyâ€™ve now, naturally, got their own series of fonts, including additional mono and condensedÂ variants.

  • This one's a bit different! Marbla is an experimental variable font that goes beyond its regular style to adopt curves and balloon-like playful variations. It doesn't seem to be generally available, but as variable fonts are still in their early days, it feels apt to share what's possible.
Ipx.
items.contentSnippet:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus



            
#â€‹621 â€” December 6, 2023 | Read on the web

          
        



  





  
  
Taking Care Beyond Code: 7 Best Design Practices for Frontend Developers â€” When a frontend engineer fails to think about the importance of design, the user experience can suffer. This post highlights the importance of a holistic approach, offering pointers and best practices to ultimately result in less bugs and overallÂ delays.
Nina Torgunakova 


  
  
ğŸš€ Â Astro 4.0 Released â€” The new major release of the Astro content-site framework is just out, including a new dev toolbar, automatic i18n routing, new view transition APIs, and more. Thereâ€™s also, experimentally, incremental content caching. Upgrading is simple â€“ an npx @astrojs/upgrade away for most folks.
Astro 


  
  
AI in Content Management Done Right â€” With AI assisting marketers, tech people can finally focus on their strengths - apply a code-first approach, avoid code debt, design high-quality structures for content, and be prepared for theÂ future.
Kontent.ai sponsor


  
  
An Informed Pre-Caching Strategy for Large Sites â€” Pre-caching, also called cache priming or cache warming, involves preemptively putting items into the cache before they are requested by a user. Ethan shares how this can be a great way to reduce expensive computations and strain on the origin server, but notes that once a site gets to a certain scale, it requires more thought than simply keeping everything in a warmedÂ cache.
Ethan Gardner 







âš¡ï¸ Quick Links
ğŸ”Ÿ It's been a decade since Troy Hunt launched the invaluable 'Have I Been Pwned' service. ThankÂ you!
ğŸ“‰ Bruce Wray looks at the stats and asks: is Firefox 'on theÂ brink'?
ğŸ¤¦ The UK government is exploring AI face detection to age-gate adultÂ content.
âŒ¨ï¸ It's from 2020, but this Advent calendar of accessibility tips remainsÂ useful.
â˜€ï¸ Do you think you'd ever use an au CSS size unit? Yes, 1au would be about 93 million miles orÂ so...Â ğŸ˜










ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion




  





  
  
Why Web Perf Tools Should Be Reporting Website CarbonÂ Emissions â€” A response to a DebugBear post explaining why the company opts not to report carbon emissions in their reports. Fershad gently suggests why they should, chiefly to allow developers the opportunity to contextualize the impact of theirÂ sites.
Fershad Irani 


  
  
sizes="auto" Pretty Much Requires Width and HeightÂ Attributes â€” Eric notes that â€˜auto-sizesâ€™ for lazy-loaded images is a fantastic addition to the web platform, but they curiously do basically require a width and height attribute.
Eric Portis 


  
  
The AI Engineer Path Just Launched ğŸš€ â€” Supercharge your web dev skills with this JS focused AI Engineer course. Frontend Focus Readers get 62% off AnnualÂ plans.
Scrimba sponsor


  
  
Does Interaction to Next Paint Actually Correlate to UserÂ Behavior? â€” Now that Interaction to Next Paint is poised to dethrone FID as the Core Web Vitals metric for responsiveness, itâ€™s time to scrutinize itsÂ effectiveness.
Cliff Crocker 


  
  
Examples of Great URL Design â€” Some examples of good URLs and why following certain patterns might be helpful. â€œTheyâ€™re not just for typing into browserÂ bars.â€
Jim Nielsen 


  
Measure LCP Sub-Parts to Improve Largest Contentful Paint
  
DebugBear 
  


  
Creating a Marquee Effect with CSS Animations
  
Ben Nadel 
  


  
How HTML Web Components are 'Having a Moment'
  
Scott Vandehey 
  


ğŸ”§  Code, Tools & Resources




  





  
  
ClassyFont: An Online Tool to Generate CSS for Your Fonts â€” Upload your web-friendly fonts and this tool will generate the necessary @font-face code. You can edit the URL paths, the font fallbacks, and the naming style (camel case, hyphen, underscore).
sakar hamasaid 


  
  
Pravatar: Avatar Placeholder Photos Under a CC0 License â€” Provides an API so you can access a random image, specifying the size, or choose a specific image from all those available by image ID, all sourced from Pexels.
simular 


  
  
A Non-Cloud Alternative to Google Forms That Has It All â€” Transform your form management. Build and edit dynamic JSON-based forms in a form builder fully integrated in yourÂ IT.
SurveyJS sponsor


  
  
Design2Code: Use AI to Convert Any Web Design Screenshot to Clean HTML/CSS Code â€” Claims to support sketches, wireframes, Figma, XD, etc. Requires an OpenAI API key and the demo video shows an HTML form being converted from an image to responsive HTML/CSS. YMMV for other types ofÂ layouts!
Mostafa Sadeghi 







ğŸ”¥ Hot fonts
I've stumbled across a handful of nice, interesting new fonts lately, so I figured I'd share a few of them here with you:


  








First up is Geist, a new pair of clean, versatile fonts from Vercel. There's two typeface variants here, Geist Sans and Geist Mono.


    

      

        


            
The much-loved Inter font just hit version 4.0. This new release has several new OpenType features, redesigns to thousands of glyphs, six additional display designs, and more. You can download it here.



        




  



      


    








      

        


            
Berkeley Mono is a lovely (paid) monofaced typeface "by software engineers, for software engineers" that's described as a "love letter to the golden era of computing". There's lots of examples here of it in use. It comes with several sets, plenty of ligatures, and has wider international/language support.



        




  



      


    








      

        


            
Snoo! Reddit recently underwent a brand redesign, and as part of that theyâ€™ve now, naturally, got their own series of fonts, including additional mono and condensedÂ variants.



        




  



      


    








  








This one's a bit different! Marbla is an experimental variable font that goes beyond its regular style to adopt curves and balloon-like playful variations. It doesn't seem to be generally available, but as variable fonts are still in their early days, it feels apt to share what's possible.









            
      
      
Ipx.

items.title: HTML hacks that shaped the Web
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹620 â€” November 29, 2023 | Read on the web

Ten Weird HTML Hacks That Shaped the Web â€” A curious history lesson looking back at old table hacks, CSS kludges, and various quirky coding strategies that helped web developers get things looking good before we had the modern tools at our disposalÂ today.

Ernie Smith

Psychology of Speed: A Guide to Perceived Performance â€” Whatâ€™s the gap between measured and perceived performance, and which should we use as our goal? This post digs into how people sense and comprehend time, giving us knowledge to make those long waits feel lessÂ frustrating.

Karlina Szczur

Identifying and Fixing Render-Blocking Resources â€” Fixing render-blocking JavaScript and CSS helps improve page load times so sneakerheads donâ€™t bounce to your competitorâ€™s site while waiting for the images of the latest drop to load. Check some of the bestÂ practices.

Sentry sponsor

A Few Ways CSS is Easier to Write in 2023 â€” Geoff notes that weâ€™re living through something of a CSS renaissance, with new features, techniques, and ideas coming fast. He shares how this breakneck speed of advancement may seem overwhelming, but these modern changes have, in practice, made CSS â€˜easierâ€™ toÂ write.

Geoff Graham (Smashing Magazine)

âš¡ï¸ Quick Links

  • ğŸ” Una shows us how to make a no-JS hamburger menu with the popoverÂ API.

  • ğŸ“± Quiche is a new modular indie-browser for iOS.

  • ğŸ–¼ï¸ A handy list of over 100 'cognitive biases and design principles'.

  • ğŸª The beta of Astro 4.0 is available, bringing it up to date with ViteÂ 5.

  • ğŸ¨ In Chrome Canary it's now possible to animate/transition the colors of a COLR font withÂ CSS.

  • ğŸ™ï¸ Off The Main Thread is a new podcast featuring Jake Archibald and Surma (both formerly of Google / HTTPÂ 203).

  • ğŸ—“ï¸ 2024's Future Frontend conference has been scheduled â€“ it's on June 13-14 in Helsinki,Â Finland.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

A Hollow Text Hover Effect in Three Lines of CSS â€” Made possible thanks to a combination of -webkit-text-fill-color, -webkit-text-stroke-width, and -webkit-text-stroke-color CSSÂ properties.

Amit Merchant

The hanging-punctuation Property â€” Browser support is quite limited, but Chris shares this â€œno-brainerâ€ CSS treatment that looks great. Hacker News had a surprising(?) amount to say about this, with lots of added context worthÂ perusing.

Chris Coyier

Web Components Eliminate JavaScript Framework Lock-in â€” Jakes notes how web components can â€œdramatically loosen the couplingâ€ of JavaScript frameworks â€”Â and in an effort to prove it they build an app where every single component is written with a differentÂ framework.

Jake Lazaroff

Build and Style Your Site Exactly How You Want â€” Drag in unstyled HTML elements, control CSS properties, and cascade changes across yourÂ site.

Webflow sponsor

Preventing Scroll â€œBounceâ€ with CSS â€” When you scroll rapidly to the top or bottom of a page you might notice a â€œbounceâ€ effect, where the browser momentarily allows you to scroll beyond the uppermost or lowermost point, before then bouncing you to the correct position. Hereâ€™s how to fixÂ that.

Michelle Barker

â–¶Â Â Resource Loading at the Cutting Edge â€” An hour-long chat, with real-world examples, that will give you a deeper understanding of the gotchas and quirks present in todayâ€™s browsers and resource loading features (prioritization, loading heuristics, etc). Also, Robin has quite the prop here..Â âš”ï¸

Robin Marx

Demystifying Web Push Notifications
Philip Bergqvist

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Animotion: A Visual CSS Animation Builder â€” Allows you to create animations by dragging, sizing, rotating, etc., which you can edit using a raw CSS keyframes editor. Also includes a number of built-in animations andÂ easings.

Zack

ai2html: Turn Adobe Illustrator Files into HTML â€” We noticed this tool being used to share graphs on a major news site and the output is pretty good. Itâ€™s frequently updated and there are lots of examples of its use. GitHubÂ repo.

The New York Times Company

ğŸ¹ Fast, Reliable 1D/2D Barcode Scanning for Web Apps with Strich â€” You donâ€™t need a native app to scan barcodes! Try the free demo app or sign up for the free, full-featured 30-dayÂ trial.

Pixelverse sponsor

Spectral.js: A Painterly Color Mixing Library â€” If you have two colors to transition between, just tweening the RGB values can result in some rather ugly intermediate colors. Spectral.js uses Kubelkaâ€“Munk theory which more closely matches how paints work for a more visually satisfyingÂ result.

Ronald van Wijnen

Vectorizer.ai: Convert your JPEG and PNG Images to SVGs with AI â€” The web app is free while in beta and works rather well on both phots and graphics â€“ though we assume the resulting raw SVG code would need someÂ optimization.

Cedar Lake Ventures

request-animation-frames: Use requestAnimationFrame Anywhere â€” The latest library from the one-man module powerhouse, Sindre Sorhus. The idea this time is to allow you to use requestAnimationFrame in any JavaScriptÂ environment.

Sindre Sorhus

Syntax.js 0.7: JavaScript Library for Easy Code Syntax Highlighting â€” No dependencies and supports all modernÂ browsers.
William Troup

11st-Starter-Kit: An Eleventy Starter Project powered by Vite, Tailwind, andÂ Alpine.js â€” Eleventy (aka 11ty) is a Node.js-powered static siteÂ generator.
Stefan Frede

Ipx.

Hereâ€™s how to fixÂ that.
Michelle Barker

ğŸ”§  Code, Tools & Resources




  





  
  
Animotion: A Visual CSS Animation Builder â€” Allows you to create animations by dragging, sizing, rotating, etc., which you can edit using a raw CSS keyframes editor. Also includes a number of built-in animations andÂ easings.

title: Frontend Focus
description: A onceâ€“weekly roundup of the best front-end news, articles and tutorials. HTML, CSS, WebGL, Canvas, browser tech, and more.
